21.28: When David saw that the Lord had answered him on the grain-floor of Ornan the Jebusite, he gave his gifts there.
21.29: The meeting tent which Moses had made in the desert was in the high place at Gibeon then. The altar of burnt gifts was there also.
21.30: But David could not go in front of it to pray to God. For he was afraid of the sword of the angel of the Lord.

22.1: Then David said, “This is the house of the Lord God. And this is the altar of burnt gifts for Israel.”
22.2: David told his men to gather the strangers who were in the land of Israel. And he had servants cut stones to build the house of God.
22.3: He gave large amounts of iron to be used for making nails for the doors of the gates, and for making the parts that hold it all together. He gave more brass than could be weighed.
22.4: And he gave too many cedar trees to number. For the Sidonians and Tyrians brought many cut cedar trees to David.
22.5: David said, “My son Solomon is young and does not yet have much learning. And the house that is to be built for the Lord must be very beautiful. It must be very great, and well-known in all lands. So I will get things ready for it to be built.” David made many things ready for it before his death.
22.6: Then he called for his son Solomon, and gave him the work of building a house for the Lord God of Israel.
22.7: David said to Solomon, “My son, I had planned to build a house to the name of the Lord my God.
22.8: But the word of the Lord came to me, saying, ‘You have taken much blood, and have fought many wars. You are not to build a house to My name, because you have poured so much blood upon the earth before Me.
22.9: See, a son will be born to you, who will be a man of peace. I will give him peace from all those who hate him on every side. His name will be Solomon. And I will give peace and quiet to Israel in his days.
22.10: He will build a house for My name. He will be My son, and I will be his father. I will make his throne in Israel last forever.’
22.11: Now, my son, may the Lord be with you and help you to do well. May you build the house of the Lord your God just as He has said you would.
22.12: Only, may the Lord give you wisdom and understanding. When He has you rule over Israel, may you keep the Law of the Lord your God.
22.13: Then you will do well, if you are careful to obey the Laws which the Lord gave to Israel by Moses. Be strong and have strength of heart. Do not be afraid or troubled.
22.14: With much trouble I have made things ready for the house of the Lord. There is gold weighing as much as 100,000 men. There is silver weighing as much as 1,000,000 men. And there is too much brass and iron to weigh. I have made wood and stone ready, and you may add to them.
22.15: You have many servants and workmen who cut and build with stones and wood. There are men who are able to do every kind of work well.
22.16: Of the gold and silver and brass and iron, there is more than enough. So get ready and work, and may the Lord be with you.”
22.17: David told all the leaders of Israel to help his son Solomon. He said to them,
22.18: “Is not the Lord your God with you? Has He not given you peace on every side? For He has given the people of the land into my hand. The land is put under my rule before the Lord and His people.
22.19: Now set your heart and soul to look to the Lord your God. Get ready and build the holy place of the Lord God. Then you may bring the special box with the Law of the Lord. You may bring the holy objects of God. And put them into the house that is to be built for the name of the Lord.”

23.1: When David was an old man, he made his son Solomon king of Israel.
23.2: He gathered together all the leaders of Israel, the religious leaders, and the Levites.
23.3: The Levites were numbered from thirty years old and older. Their number was 38,000.
23.4: Of these, 24,000 were to watch over the work of the Lord’s house. There were 6,000 who were leaders and men who were to judge.
23.5: There were 4,000 gate-keepers. And 4,000 were praising the Lord with the things for playing music that David had made.
23.6: David divided them into groups by the sons of Levi, Gershon and Kohath and Merari.
23.7: The sons of Gershon were Ladan and Shimei.
23.8: The sons of Ladan were Jehiel the first, then Zetham and Joel, three in all.
23.9: The three sons of Shimei were Shelemoth, Haziel and Haran. These were the heads of the fathers’ houses of Ladan.
23.10: And the sons of Shimei were Jahath, Zina, Jeush and Beriah. These four were the sons of Shimei.
23.11: Jahath was the first, and Zizah the second. But Jeush and Beriah did not have many sons, so they were numbered together as one father’s house.
23.12: The four sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron and Uzziel.
23.13: The sons of Amram were Aaron and Moses. Aaron was set apart for holy work, he and his sons forever. They were to burn special perfume before the Lord, and do His work. And they were to pray for good to come to the people in the Lord’s name forever.
23.14: But the names of the sons of Moses the man of God were among the family of Levi.
23.15: The sons of Moses were Gershom and Eliezer.
23.16: The son of Gershom was Shebuel the leader.
23.17: The son of Eliezer was Rehabiah the leader. Eliezer had no other sons. But Rehabiah had many sons.
23.18: The son of Izhar was Shelomith the leader.
23.19: The sons of Hebron were Jeriah the first, Amariah the second, Jehaziel the third, and Jekameam the fourth.
23.20: The sons of Uzziel were Micah the first, and Isshiah the second.
23.21: The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi. The sons of Mahli were Eleazar and Kish.
23.22: Eleazar died and had no sons, only daughters. Their brothers the sons of Kish married them.
23.23: The three sons of Mushi were Mahli and Eder and Jeremoth.
23.24: These were the sons of Levi by their fathers’ houses. They were the heads of the fathers’ houses of those whose names were numbered from twenty years old and older. They were to do the work of the Lord’s house.
23.25: For David said, “The Lord God of Israel has given peace to his people. And He lives in Jerusalem forever.
23.26: The Levites do not need to carry the meeting tent and all the parts for its work any longer.”
23.27: For by the last words of David the sons of Levi were numbered, from twenty years old and older.
23.28: He said, “Their duties are to help Aaron’s sons with the work of the Lord’s house, in the open spaces and in the rooms. They are to make clean all the holy things, and do any work needed to be done in the house of God.
23.29: They are to take care of the holy bread, the fine flour for a grain gift, and the bread without yeast. They are to take care of what is baked, and what is well mixed, of all the right amounts.
23.30: They are to stand every morning and evening to thank and praise the Lord.
23.31: And they are to give all the burnt gifts to the Lord on the Days of Rest, the new moons, and the special days. They are to do this before the Lord all the time, by the number set by the Law.
23.32: In this way they are to take care of the meeting tent, the holy place, and help their brothers the sons of Aaron, for the work of the Lord’s house.

24.1: These were the family groups of the sons of Aaron. The sons of Aaron were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
24.2: Nadab and Abihu died before their father died. They had no sons, so Eleazar and Ithamar became the religious leaders.
24.3: With the help of Zadok of the sons of Eleazar and Ahimelech of the sons of Ithamar, David divided them by their given duties.
24.4: More leaders were found from the sons of Eleazar than the sons of Ithamar. So they were divided in this way. There were sixteen heads of families of the sons of Eleazar. And there were eight heads of families of the sons of Ithamar.
24.5: They were divided by drawing names, all alike. For there were leaders of the holy place and leaders of God, from both the sons of Eleazar and Ithamar.
24.6: The writer Shemaiah, the Levite son of Nethanel, wrote down their names. He wrote them in front of the king, the princes, Zadok the religious leader, Ahimelech the son of Abiathar, and the heads of the families of the religious leaders and of the Levites. One family was taken for Eleazar, and one for Ithamar.
24.7: The first name drawn was Jehoiarib, the second Jedaiah,
24.8: the third Harim, the fourth Seorim,
24.9: the fifth Malchijah, the sixth Mijamin.
24.10: The seventh name was Hakkoz, the eighth Abijah,
24.11: the ninth Jeshua, the tenth Shecaniah,
24.12: the eleventh Eliashib, the twelfth Jakim.
24.13: The thirteenth name was Huppah, the fourteenth Jeshebeab,
24.14: the fifteenth Bilgah, the sixteenth Immer.
24.15: The seventeenth name was Hezir, the eighteenth Happizzez,
24.16: the nineteenth Pethahiah, the twentieth Jehezkel.
24.17: The twenty-first name was Jachin, the twenty-second Gamul,
24.18: the twenty-third Delaiah, and the twenty-fourth Maaziah.
24.19: This was the way they were to come on duty to work in the Lord’s house. It was a rule given to them through their father Aaron, just as the Lord God of Israel had told him.
24.20: The rest of the sons of Levi were Shubael of the sons of Amram, Jehdeiah of the sons of Shubael,
24.21: and Isshiah was the first of the sons of Rehabiah.
24.22: There was Shelomoth of the Izharites, and Jahath of the sons of Shelomoth.
24.23: Of the sons of Hebron, there were Jeriah the first, Amariah the second, Jahaziel the third, and Jekameam the fourth.
24.24: There was Micah of the sons of Uzziel, and Shamir of the sons of Micah.
24.25: The brother of Micah was Isshiah. There was Zechariah of the sons of Isshiah.
24.26: The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi. Jaaziah’s son was Beno.
24.27: The sons of Merari by Jaaziah were Beno, Shoham, Zaccur and Ibri.
24.28: His son by Mahli was Eleazar, who had no sons.
24.29: His son by Kish was Jerahmeel.
24.30: And the sons of Mushi were Mahli, Eder and Jerimoth. These were the sons of the Levites by their families.
24.31: The head of each family and his younger brother drew names just as their brothers the sons of Aaron did. They drew them in front of King David, Zadok, Ahimelech, and the heads of the families of the religious leaders and of the Levites.

25.1: David and the captains of the army set apart for the work some of the sons of Asaph, of Heman and of Jeduthun. They were to speak God’s Word while harps and timbrels were playing. These are the names of those who served in this way.
25.2: The sons of Asaph were: Zaccur, Joseph, Nethaniah and Asharelah. They were led by Asaph, who spoke for God under the leading of the king.
25.3: The six sons of Jeduthun were: Gedaliah, Zeri, Jeshaiah, Shimei, Hashabiah and Mattithiah. They were led by their father Jeduthun, who spoke God’s Word using the harp, giving thanks and praising the Lord.
25.4: The sons of Heman were: Bukkiah, Mattaniah, Uzziel, Shebuel, Jerimoth, Hananiah, Hanani, Eliathah, Giddalti, Romamtiezer, Joshbekashah, Mallothi, Hothir and Mahazioth.
25.5: All these were the sons of Heman the king’s man of God, to honor him by the Words of God. God gave Heman fourteen sons and three daughters.
25.6: All of them were led by their father to sing in the Lord’s house. They sang and played timbrels and harps, serving in the house of God. Asaph, Jeduthun and Heman were led by the king.
25.7: The number of those and their brothers who were taught to sing to the Lord, all who were very good singers, was 288.
25.8: They drew names for their work, the young and old alike, also the teacher and the one who was taught.
25.9: These are how the names were drawn. First was Joseph the son of Asaph. The second was Gedaliah. Together with his brothers and sons, there were twelve.
25.10: The third was Zaccur. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.11: The fourth was Izri. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.12: The fifth was Nethaniah. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.13: The sixth was Bukkiah. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.14: The seventh was Jesharelah. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.15: The eighth was Jeshaiah. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.16: The ninth was Mattaniah. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.17: The tenth was Shimei. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.18: The eleventh was Azarel. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.19: The twelfth was Hashabiah. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.20: The thirteenth was Shubael. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.21: The fourteenth was Mattithiah. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.22: The fifteenth was Jeremoth. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.23: The sixteenth was Hananiah. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.24: The seventeenth was Joshbekashah. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.25: The eighteenth was Hanani. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.26: The nineteenth was Mallothi. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.27: The twentieth was Eliathah. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.28: The twenty-first was Hothir. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.29: The twenty-second was Giddalti. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.30: The twenty-third was Mahazioth. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.
25.31: And the twenty-fourth was Romamti-ezer. With his sons and brothers there were twelve.

26.1: The gate-keepers were divided up. Of the Korahites there was Meshelemiah the son of Kore, a son of Asaph.
26.2: Meshelemiah’s sons were Zechariah the first-born, Jediael the second, Zebadiah the third, Jathniel the fourth.
26.3: Elam was his fifth son, Johanan the sixth, Eliehoenai the seventh.
26.4: Obed-edom’s sons were Shemaiah the first-born, Jehozabad the second, Joah the third, Sacar the fourth, Nethanel the fifth.
26.5: Ammiel was his sixth son, Issachar the seventh, and Peullethai the eighth. God had brought good to the father.
26.6: To his son Shemaiah sons were born who ruled over their father’s house. They were strong, able men with strength of heart.
26.7: The sons of Shemaiah were Othni, Rephael, Obed and Elzabad. Their brothers, Elihu and Semachiah, were strong and able men.
26.8: All these were sons of Obed-edom. They and their sons and brothers were able men with strength for the work. There were sixty-two men from Obed-edom.
26.9: Meshelemiah had sons and brothers, eighteen strong and able men.
26.10: These are the sons of Hosah, one of Merari’s sons: Shimri was the first. (He was not the first-born, but his father made him first.)
26.11: Hilkiah was his second, Tebaliah the third, and Zechariah the fourth. Hosah had thirteen sons and brothers in all.
26.12: These leaders of the families who were set apart as gate-keepers were given duties like their brothers to work in the Lord’s house.
26.13: The families drew names by their fathers’ houses, the small and the large alike, for every gate.
26.14: Shelemiah’s name was drawn for the east gate. Then they drew the name of his son Zechariah for the north gate. Zechariah used much wisdom talking with people.
26.15: Obed-edom’s name was drawn for the south gate. And his sons were to watch the store-house.
26.16: Shuppim and Hosah’s names were drawn for the west gate beside the gate of Shallecheth, on the road that goes up a hill. Each one was given his duty to watch.
26.17: There were six Levites on the east. There were four each day on the north. There were four each day on the south. There were two at one time at the store-house.
26.18: There were four at the road. And there were two at the place between the west wall of the Lord’s house and the wall of the open space.
26.19: These were the way the gate-keepers of the sons of Korah and Merari were divided.
26.20: Their brothers the Levites watched over the riches of the house of God and the riches of the holy gifts.
26.21: The sons of Ladan, who were Gershonites through the family group of Ladan were Jehielites.
26.22: The sons of Jehieli, Zetham and his brother Joel, watched over the riches of the house of the Lord.
26.23: Of the Amramites, the Izharites, the Hebronites and the Uzzielites,
26.24: Shebuel the son of Gershom, son of Moses, was the captain over the riches.
26.25: His brothers by Eliezer were Rehabiah his son, Jeshaiah his son, Joram his son, Zichri his son, and Shelomoth his son.
26.26: Shelomoth and his brothers watched over all the riches of the holy gifts. These gifts had been set apart by King David and the heads of the fathers’ houses, the captains of thousands and hundreds, and the captains of the army.
26.27: They set apart things taken in battles to do the work needed on the house of the Lord.
26.28: Samuel the man of God had set apart gifts. So had Saul the son of Kish, Abner the son of Ner, and Joab the son of Zeruiah, and everyone who had set apart anything. All these holy gifts were in the care of Shelomoth and his brothers.
26.29: Of the Izharites, Chenaniah and his sons were given outside duties for Israel. They were leaders and men who decide who is guilty or not.
26.30: Of the Hebronites, Hashabiah and his brothers were leaders of Israel west of the Jordan. They were 1,700 able men who did all the work of the Lord and the work of the king.
26.31: Of the Hebronites, Jerijah was the leader of the Hebronites by their families and fathers’ houses. Very able men were found among them at Jazer in Gilead in the fortieth year of David’s rule.
26.32: Jerijah and his brothers were 2,700 able men, heads of fathers’ houses. King David chose them to take care of all the duties of God and of the king, among the Reubenites, the Gadites and the half-family group of the Manassites.

27.1: These were the sons of Israel, the heads of fathers’ houses. They were the leaders of thousands and of hundreds. These were the captains who worked for the king in anything to do with the armies which came in and went out every month of the year. There were 24,000 men in each army.
27.2: Jashobeam the son of Zabdiel was the leader of the first army for the first month. There were 24,000 in his army.
27.3: He was a son of Perez, and head of all the captains of the army for the first month.
27.4: Dodai the Ahohite was the leader of the army for the second month. Mikloth was the head captain. There were 24,000 in his army.
27.5: The third leader of the army for the third month was Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada the religious leader. There were 24,000 in his army.
27.6: This is the Benaiah who was the strong man of the thirty, and leader of the thirty. Ammizabad his son was captain of his army.
27.7: The fourth leader for the fourth month was Asahel the brother of Joab, and Zebadiah his son after him. There were 24,000 in his army.
27.8: The fifth leader for the fifth month was Shamhuth the Izrahite. There were 24,000 in his army.
27.9: The sixth for the sixth month was Ira the son of Ikkesh the Tekoite. There were 24,000 in his army.
27.10: The seventh for the seventh month was Helez the Pelonite of the sons of Ephraim. There were 24,000 in his army.
27.11: The eighth for the eighth month was Sibbecai the Hushathite of the Zerahites. There were 24,000 in his army.
27.12: The ninth for the ninth month was Abiezer the Anathothite of the Benjamites. There were 24,000 in his army.
27.13: The tenth for the tenth month was Maharai the Netophathite of the Zerahites. There were 24,000 in his army.
27.14: The eleventh for the eleventh month was Benaiah the Pirathonite of the sons of Ephraim. There were 24,000 in his army.
27.15: The twelfth for the twelfth month was Heldai the Netophathite of Othniel. There were 24,000 in his army.
27.16: The leaders of the family groups of Israel were: Eliezer the son of Zichri was the head captain of the Reubenites; Shephatiah the son of Maacah led the Simeonites.
27.17: Hashabiah the son of Kemuel led the sons of Levi; Zadok led the sons of Aaron.
27.18: Elihu, one of David’s brothers, led the sons of Judah; Omri the son of Michael led the sons of Issachar;
27.19: Ishmaiah the son of Obadiah led the sons of Zebulun; Jeremoth the son of Azriel led the sons of Naphtali;
27.20: Hoshea the son of Azaziah led the sons of Ephraim; Joel the son of Pedaiah led the half-family group of Manasseh;
27.21: Iddo the son of Zechariah led the half-family group of Manasseh in Gilead; Jaasiel the son of Abner led the sons of Benjamin;
27.22: And Azarel the son of Jeroham led the sons of Dan. These were the leaders of the families of Israel.
27.23: But David did not number those younger than twenty years old because the Lord had promised to make Israel many, as the stars of heaven.
27.24: Joab the son of Zeruiah had begun to number them, but did not finish. Anger came upon Israel because of this. So the number was not put into the book of the chronicles of King David.
27.25: Azmaveth the son of Adiel was over the king’s store-houses. Jonathan the son of Uzziah was over the store-houses in the country, in the cities, in the towns, and in the towers.
27.26: Ezri the son of Chelub was over those who worked in the fields, plowing and planting.
27.27: Shimei the Ramathite was over the grape-fields. Zabdi the Shiphmite was over the fruit of the grape-fields for the wine.
27.28: Baalhanan the Gederite was over the olive and sycamore trees in the plains. Joash was captain of the stores of oil.
27.29: Shitrai the Sharonite was over the cattle which were eating in the fields of Sharon. Shaphat the son of Adlai was over the cattle in the valleys.
27.30: Obil the Ishmaelite was over the camels. Jehdeiah the Meronothite was over the donkeys.
27.31: And Jaziz the Hagrite was over the flocks. All these were over all that belonged to King David.
27.32: Jonathan, the brother of David’s father, used much wisdom talking with people. And he was a writer. Jehiel the son of Hachmoni taught the king’s sons.
27.33: Ahithophel talked about problems with the king. Hushai the Archite was the king’s friend.
27.34: Jehoiada the son of Benaiah, and Abaiathar, talked with the king after Ahithophel. And Joab was the captain of the king’s army.

28.1: David gathered together all the leaders of Israel. There were leaders of the family groups, and leaders of the armies that served the king. There were captains of thousands, and of hundreds. There were leaders who cared for all the things and animals belonging to the king and his sons. There were the leaders and all the powerful soldiers.
28.2: Then King David stood up and said, “Listen to me, my brothers and my people. I had wanted to build a house of rest for the special box with the Law of the Lord, a place for God to rest His feet, so I had made plans to build it.
28.3: But God said to me, ‘You must not build a house for My name, because you are a man of war and blood.’
28.4: But the Lord, the God of Israel, chose me from all the house of my father to be the king of Israel forever. For He has chosen Judah to be a leader. And in the house of Judah, my father’s house, and among my father’s sons, He was pleased to make me king of all Israel.
28.5: The Lord has given me many sons. And of all my sons, He has chosen my son Solomon to sit on the throne of the nation of the Lord over Israel.
28.6: He said to me, ‘Your son Solomon is the one who will build My house and My open spaces. For I have chosen him to be My son, and I will be his father.
28.7: I will make him king forever, if he is faithful to obey My Words and My Laws, as he is doing now.’
28.8: So now I say to you in front of all these people of Israel, and in the hearing of our God: Be careful to do all the Law of the Lord your God. If you obey you will receive the good land and also leave it to your children after you forever.
28.9: “As for you, my son Solomon, know the God of your father. Serve Him with a whole heart and a willing mind. For the Lord looks into all hearts, and understands every plan and thought. If you look to Him, He will let you find Him. But if you turn away from Him, He will turn away from you forever.
28.10: Listen now, for the Lord has chosen you to build a place of worship. Be strong, and do it.”
28.11: Then David gave his son Solomon the plan of the porch of the Lord’s house, its buildings, and its store-houses. He gave him the plan of the rooms on its second floor, its inside rooms, and the room for the mercy-seat.
28.12: He gave him the plan of all he had in mind. It showed the open spaces of the Lord’s house, and all the rooms around them. It showed the store-houses of the house of God, and the store-houses of the holy things.
28.13: He gave him the plan for the way the religious leaders and the Levites were to be divided up for all the work of the Lord’s house. He told how all the objects were to be used in worship in the Lord’s house.
28.14: David gave the weight of all the gold objects to be used in each part of worship. He gave the weight for all the silver objects to be used in each part of the worship.
28.15: The plan gave the weight of gold for the gold lamp-stands and gold lamps. It gave the weight of each lamp-stand and its lamps. It gave the weight of silver for the silver lamp-stands. It gave the weight of each lamp-stand and its lamps, by the use of each lamp-stand.
28.16: It gave the weight of gold for each table of holy bread, and of silver for the silver tables.
28.17: It gave the weight of the meat-hooks, the pots and the cups of pure gold. It gave the weight for each of the gold and silver pots.
28.18: It gave the weight of the fine gold of the altar of special perfume, and of the gold wagon and of the cherubim that spread out their wings and covered the special box with the Law of the Lord.
28.19: David said, “This is in writing because His hand was upon me. He helped me to know all the plan.”
28.20: Then David said to his son Solomon, “Be strong. Have strength of heart, and do it. Do not be afraid or troubled, for the Lord God, my God, is with you. He will not stop helping you. He will not leave you until all the work of the house of the Lord is finished.
28.21: See, the religious leaders and the Levites are divided up to do all the work of the house of God. Every willing man who is able to do a special work will help you in all that is to be done. The leaders and all the people will do what you say.”

29.1: Then King David said to all the people, “My son Solomon is the one God has chosen. He is still young and has not had much time to know what to do. It is a very big work because this beautiful house is not for man, but for the Lord God.
29.2: I have given all that I have been able to give for the house of my God. I have given the gold for the things of gold, the silver for the things of silver, and the brass for the things of brass. I have given the iron for the things of iron, and the wood for the things of wood. I have given stones of much worth, stones for setting, silver-white stones, and stones of different colors. I have given all kinds of stones of much worth, and many smooth, special white stones.
29.3: The house of my God means much to me. I have much gold and silver and I give it to the house of my God, together with all I have already given for the holy house.
29.4: I gave gold weighing as much as 3,000 men, of the gold of Ophir. I gave fine silver weighing as much as 7,000 men, to cover the walls of the house.
29.5: I gave gold for the things of gold, and silver for the things of silver for all the work done by the able men. Now who is willing to give himself and be set apart today to the Lord?”
29.6: Then the rulers of the families gave because they wanted to. The leaders of the family groups of Israel, the captains of thousands and of hundreds, and those who watched over the king’s work gave because they wanted to.
29.7: For the work of the house of God, they gave gold weighing as much as 5,000 men, and 10,000 gold pieces. They gave silver weighing as much as 10,000 men. They gave brass weighing as much as 18,000 men, and iron weighing as much as 100,000 men.
29.8: And whoever had stones of much worth gave them to the store-house of the house of the Lord, in the care of Jehiel the Gershonite.
29.9: Then the people were filled with joy because they had been so willing to give. They gave their gift to the Lord with a whole heart. And King David was filled with great joy.
29.10: So David praised the Lord in front of all the people. He said, “Honor and thanks be to You, O Lord God of Israel our father, forever and ever.
29.11: O Lord, You have great power, shining-greatness and strength. Yes, everything in heaven and on earth belongs to You. You are the King, O Lord. And You are honored as head over all.
29.12: Both riches and honor come from You. You rule over all. Power and strength are in Your hand. The power is in Your hand to make great and to give strength to all.
29.13: So now, our God, we thank You. We praise Your great and honored name.
29.14: “But who am I and who are my people, that we should be able to give so much? For all things come from You. We have given You only what already belongs to You.
29.15: We are strangers before You. We are just staying here for a time, as all our fathers did. Our days on the earth are like a shadow, and without hope.
29.16: O Lord our God, from Your hand are all these many things that we have given to build You a house for Your holy name. It all belongs to You.
29.17: O my God, I know that You test the heart and are pleased with what is right. I have given these things because I have wanted to with a clean heart. And now I have seen with joy how Your people who are here give gifts to You because they want to.
29.18: O Lord, the God of Abraham, Isaac and Israel, our fathers, keep this forever in the thoughts of the hearts of Your people. Lead their hearts to You.
29.19: Give my son Solomon a perfect heart to keep Your Words and Your Laws and to obey them all. And so let him build the beautiful house I have planned and given for.”
29.20: Then David said to all the people, “Now praise the Lord your God.” And all the people gave praise to the Lord, the God of their fathers. They bowed low to the ground before the Lord and the king.
29.21:
On the next day they killed animals and gave burnt gifts in worship to the Lord.
They gave 1,000 bulls, 1,000 rams and 1,000 lambs, with their drink gifts. They gave many gifts in worship for all Israel.
29.22:
So they ate and drank that day with great joy before the Lord.
They made David’s son Solomon king a second time. They poured oil on him to set him apart as ruler for the Lord. And they set Zadok apart as religious leader.
29.23: Then Solomon sat on the throne of the Lord as king instead of his father David. Everything went well for him, and all Israel obeyed him.
29.24: All the leaders and the powerful men and all the sons of King David promised to be faithful to King Solomon.
29.25: The Lord brought much honor to Solomon in the eyes of all Israel. He gave him greater power than any king before him in Israel.
29.26: So David the son of Jesse ruled over all Israel.
29.27: And he ruled over Israel for forty years. He ruled in Hebron seven years, and in Jerusalem thirty-three years.
29.28: Then he died as an old man. He had lived many years, had many riches and much honor. And his son Solomon ruled in his place.
29.29: The acts of King David, from first to last, are written in the books of Samuel, Nathan, and Gad, the men of God.
29.30: They tell of all his rule, his power, and of the things which happened to him, to Israel, and to all the nations of the lands.
